item.title: What is behind spike in pothole related call-outs?
item.content:encoded: The AA says pothole-related call outs in January were up by 18% across the UK, with 6,235 in the East of England alone.

item.title: Why this school will ditch a shirt, tie and blazer from its uniform
item.content:encoded: The school says the move is practical - but it echoes a wider debate over the role of uniforms.

item.title: The £10 tricks I used to make my rented room into a home
item.content:encoded: Talented tenants share decor hacks that won't cost you a fortune - or your deposit.

item.title: The £10 tricks I used to make my rented room into a home
item.content:encoded: Talented tenants share decor hacks that won't cost you a fortune - or your deposit.

item.title: FBI analysing recovered glove that appears to match those worn in Guthrie suspect video
item.content:encoded: The FBI says it recovered a DNA sample from the glove, which was found in a field a few miles from Guthrie's home.

item.title: UK considering significant increase to defence spending
item.content:encoded: The prime minister is considering meeting a 3% defence-spending target five years earlier than planned, the BBC learns.

item.title: The Papers: 'Truth is antidote to Putin's poison' and 'Europe sabotage campaign'
item.content:encoded: The aftermath following the UK saying Russia killed opposition leader Alexei Navalny with a frog toxin continues to lead a number of today's papers.

item.title: Ministers want to reform SEND - but they are treading very carefully
item.content:encoded: The government is expected to outline its plan to overhaul the complex system of support for children with special educational needs and disabilities (SEND) in England soon.

item.title: Cabinet secretary frontrunner previously spoken to about management style
item.content:encoded: Dame Antonia Romeo was found to have no case to answer over one complaint nine years ago.

item.title: America's Next Top Model shaped reality TV, but should it ever have been made?
item.content:encoded: A new Netflix documentary will finally see Tyra Banks and her fellow judges address some of the most controversial scandals from the reality show.

item.title: Ex-church minister who admitted child sexual abuse to BBC still free years later
item.content:encoded: Robert Corfield, who admitted abusing a child to the BBC, was a minister in a shadowy church known as The Truth.

item.title: Trump has big plans for Venezuela's oil but are they feasible?
item.content:encoded: The US president wants American energy firms to start extracting the crude but they are reluctant.

item.title: 'Dragged out and set on fire' - the Bangladesh mob killing that shocked the world
item.content:encoded: In December, Hindu factory worker Dipu Das was lynched in Bangladesh, igniting global outrage.

item.title: No free pass for internet platforms on child safety, Starmer says
item.content:encoded: The government announces a consultation on online safety, including on a possible social media ban for under-16s.

item.title: GB's Muir in big air final - Monday's guide
item.content:encoded: What's happening and who to look out for at the 2026 Winter Olympics in Milan-Cortina.

item.title: GB edged out in thriller but semis still in sights
item.content:encoded: GB's men's curlers suffer their second defeat of the Winter Olympics but remain on course for a semi-final place, after following a win over Germany with a nerve-shredding extra-end loss to Switzerland on Sunday.

item.title: US attorney general criticised after saying all Epstein files have been released
item.content:encoded: Lawmakers, including those who wrote the law requiring their publication, argue the release is insufficient.

item.title: The curious case of Chermiti in Rohl's Rangers revolution
item.content:encoded: BBC Scotland looks at Youssef Chermiti's impact for Rangers against Hearts and beyond.

item.title: Ice and flood warnings for parts of northern UK as cool weather continues
item.content:encoded: More than 70 flood warnings have also been issued by the Environment Agency after heavy rain.

item.title: What is the dart frog toxin allegedly used to kill Alexei Navalny?
item.content:encoded: The toxin, epibatidine, can be found in frogs in the wild in South America or manufactured in a lab.

item.title: Team GB clinches second gold of day at Winter Olympics
item.content:encoded: Team GB wins two Winter Olympic titles on one day for the first time as Matt Weston and Tabitha Stoecker clinch mixed team skeleton gold.

item.title: Weston and Stoecker win GB's second Olympic gold of day
item.content:encoded: Matt Weston becomes the first Briton to win two gold medals at a Winter Olympics with a thrilling victory in the mixed team skeleton alongside Tabitha Stoecker.

item.title: Why first gold on snow has been just a matter of time
item.content:encoded: An Olympic gold medal on snow has long seemed like the impossible for Team GB. But for those in the know, it has been just a matter of time.

item.title: Will anyone stop 'massive favourites' France in Six Nations?
item.content:encoded: France were at their swaggering best in Wales to extend their bid for a first Six Nations Grand Slam since 2022 - so who could stop them?

item.title: US boards second tanker in Indian Ocean after tracking it from Caribbean
item.content:encoded: The US accuses the Veronica III of violating a "quarantine" on oil shipments from Venezuela.

item.title: Weston and Stoecker make history as Team GB win third Olympic gold
item.content:encoded: Matt Weston and Tabby Stoecker make history as they claim gold in the mixed team skeleton at the 2026 Winter Olympics. Weston becomes the first Team GB athlete to win two gold medals in a single Winter Olympics.

item.title: 'India v Pakistan becoming a political rivalry rather than sporting one'
item.content:encoded: After weeks of debate about whether Pakistan's fixture against India would go ahead at the T20 World Cup, the action failed to deliver and it left the rivalry feeling more political than sporting.

item.title: Eleven killed in Israeli strikes on Gaza, rescuers say
item.content:encoded: The Palestinian Red Crescent say a strike on a tent encampment in northern Gaza killed at least six people.

item.title: Andrew's time as trade envoy should be investigated, says Vince Cable
item.content:encoded: The former prince's alleged actions were "totally unacceptable", the ex-business secretary says.

item.title: Andrew's time as trade envoy should be investigated, says Vince Cable
item.content:encoded: The former prince's alleged actions were "totally unacceptable", the ex-business secretary says.

item.title: 'A throwback' - Wolves beat Grimsby in FA Cup mudbath
item.content:encoded: Premier League Wolves edge League Two Grimsby in an "old school cup tie" which provided an FA Cup "throwback".

item.title: Regis adds to parents' legacy with first UK title
item.content:encoded: Renee Regis continues in father John Regis' footsteps by winning the women's 200m title at the UK Athletics Indoor Championships in Birmingham.

item.title: Ukraine's ex-energy minister detained while attempting to leave country
item.content:encoded: His detention comes as he faces legal proceedings after being dismissed in a corruption scandal.

item.title: France hammer Wales to keep Grand Slam dream alive
item.content:encoded: France keep alive their hopes of a Grand Slam with an eight-try hammering of woeful Wales - their 13th successive Six Nations defeat.

item.title: Gender pay gap won't close for another 30 years, warns trade unions group
item.content:encoded: The average woman employee "effectively works for 47 days of the year for free," according to the Trades Union Congress.

item.title: 'Fast-spreading' measles outbreak hits several schools in London
item.content:encoded: A number of children have been hospitalised as officials urge families to check they are up to date with their vaccines.

item.title: Klaebo wins record ninth Winter Olympic gold
item.content:encoded: Johannes Hoesflot Klaebo, Norway's king of cross-country skiing, becomes the Winter Olympics' outright most successful athlete with a record ninth gold medal.

item.title: Last chance for pensioners to get free air fryers
item.content:encoded: The council has handed out 15,000 free air fryers help people with the cost of living.

item.title: Children 'weaponised' by both sides of trans debate, says author of gender identity report
item.content:encoded: Clinician Dr Hilary Cass says "people at the extremes" had caused a lot of distress for young people.

item.title: What the Nigella Lawson effect will mean for the Great British Bake Off
item.content:encoded: What joining Channel 4's famous tent could mean for the TV cook's career and the baking show.

item.title: Could Manchester be a model for the UK to kickstart growth?
item.content:encoded: With an annual growth rate of 3.1%, Manchester's economy has performed twice as well as that of the UK as a whole.

item.title: The spectacular multimillion-euro heist nobody noticed
item.content:encoded: How did the thieves know exactly where the vault was and why did no-one hear the drill? Was it an inside job?

item.title: Craft beer maker Brewdog put up for sale
item.content:encoded: Consultants Alix Partners have been brought in to oversee the sales process which could lead to the businesses being broken up.

item.title: Rising vet costs leave charity with £400k bill
item.content:encoded: The group, based in Solihull and Wolverhampton, says its vet bills are costing them more.

item.title: Andrew facing claim he shared Treasury document with banking contact
item.content:encoded: Reports suggest the former prince shared a Treasury document when he was serving as trade envoy.

item.title: Are families being priced out of restaurants?
item.content:encoded: The restaurant industry says it is facing a double whammy - rising costs and customers with less money.

item.title: Heathrow not crowded but people walk in 'wrong place', says boss
item.content:encoded: Chief executive Thomas Woldbye says Europeans and Brits keep "crashing into each other" because they walk on different sides.

item.title: Amazon's Ring ends deal with surveillance firm after backlash
item.content:encoded: A Super Bowl advert had sparked new scrutiny of the smart doorbell company's privacy practices.

item.title: Inflation eases in US as prices for used cars fall
item.content:encoded: Prices rose by 2.4% in the year to January, the latest official figures show, the slowest pace since May.

item.title: Head of Dubai-based ports giant quits after Epstein links revealed
item.content:encoded: Sultan Ahmed bin Sulayem’s exit comes after files showed he appears to have exchanged hundreds of emails with Epstein.

item.title: Why you should consider switching bank accounts
item.content:encoded: Martin Lewis explains why now might be a good time to think about changing your bank account.

item.title: Why you should consider switching bank accounts
item.content:encoded: Martin Lewis explains why now might be a good time to think about changing your bank account.

item.title: Hello Kitty designer steps down after 46 years
item.content:encoded: Yuko Yamaguchi oversaw the feline character's rise to global icon status.

item.title: Trump revokes key climate ruling which he says has made cars pricier
item.content:encoded: The White House calls it the largest deregulation in US history, but environmentalists say it will prove costly for Americans.

item.title: AirAsia accused by artist for allegedly using his work without consent
item.content:encoded: A Penang-based street artist says his work has been "reproduced" as part of a livery on an aircraft

item.title: AI safety leader says 'world is in peril' and quits to study poetry
item.content:encoded: It comes in the same week an OpenAI researcher resigned amid concerns about its decision to start testing ChatGPT ads.

item.title: Taylor Swift asks US government to block 'Swift Home' trademark
item.content:encoded: Her team argued that a bedding firm's designs showed similarities to her trademarked signature.

item.title: Costs from Trump's tariffs paid mainly by US firms and consumers, NY Fed says
item.content:encoded: Last year, collective import tariff rates on various goods coming into the US more than tripled.

item.title: AI coding platform's flaws allow BBC reporter to be hacked
item.content:encoded: Vibe-coding tools - which let people without coding skills create apps using AI - are exploding in popularity.

item.title: Rain and politics driving up half-term holiday bookings, travel agents say
item.content:encoded: The Advantage Travel Partnerships says rain plus the political environment is creating a "powerful psychological need for escape".

item.title: The US economy is growing - so where are all the jobs?
item.content:encoded: As hiring rates and job openings drop, some worry a tough job market could be here to stay.

item.title: Get a grip: Robotics firms struggle to develop hands
item.content:encoded: Developing a durable and affordable hand is one of the biggest challenges in robotics.

item.title: US antitrust chief resigns amid tensions with Trump officials
item.content:encoded: The departure of Gail Slater has raised questions about the White House's approach to policing big mergers and monopolies.

item.title: FTC warns Apple over alleged lack of conservative news
item.content:encoded: The tech giant is facing pressure over claims that its news app does not feature articles from conservative outlets.

item.title: Salmon exports remain high but Scotch whisky falls
item.content:encoded: Scottish salmon exports increased in tonnage by 9%, while the volume of Scotch whisky exports dropped by 4.3%.

item.title: Tesco plans to give under-18s Clubcard access this year
item.content:encoded: Consumer outlet Which? has been campaigning on access to loyalty schemes, calling it a "huge win for shoppers".

item.title: Probe ordered into Daily Mail owner's £500m takeover of Telegraph
item.content:encoded: Culture Secretary Lisa Nandy orders a review of the deal on public interest and competition grounds.

item.title: Thousands queue as beauty store arrives on island of Ireland
item.content:encoded: Almost 2,000 people joined the queue for the opening of a new store in Belfast this morning.

item.title: 'Tens of thousands' affected by law firm collapse
item.content:encoded: The Solicitors Regulation Authority say an investigation into PM Law's collapse is ongoing.

item.title: Who is billionaire Sir Jim Ratcliffe and how did he make his money?
item.content:encoded: The industrialist and Manchester United co-owner has apologised over comments he made about immigration.

item.title: Reeves says 'more to do' after sluggish GDP growth
item.content:encoded: The chancellor's comments came after figures showed the UK economy saw a lacklustre end to 2025.

item.title: The Bottom Line
item.content:encoded: Why do private landlords attract so much criticism – and how fair is it?

item.title: Civil service pension backlog 'overwhelmed' Capita, boss says
item.content:encoded: Thousands of retiring civil servants have been left without pension payments causing hardship for some.

item.title: The Dutch love four-day working weeks, but are they sustainable?
item.content:encoded: The Netherlands has the lowest working hours in Europe, but some say it is harming its economy.

item.title: Has Jeff Bezos brought down the Washington Post?
item.content:encoded: The Amazon boss has gutted a third of the workforce at the iconic newspaper

item.title: Netflix and Paramount are battling for Warner Bros. Who is likely to win?
item.content:encoded: What to know about the two firms' blockbuster battle to control Warner Bros Discovery.

item.title: How £50m 'fish disco' could save farmland
item.content:encoded: Innovative tech scares fish away from nuclear cooling pipes.

item.title: Why food fraud persists, even with improving tech
item.content:encoded: Even with sophisticated technology it is still difficult to detect fake foods.

item.title: Plane makers chase Asia's super-rich with luxe new private jets
item.content:encoded: Parts of the aviation industry are shifting towards wealthy customers and selling a more luxurious type of international travel.

item.title: Kids can be the harshest critics…
item.content:encoded: The candidates test their story on a group of kids.

item.title: Should you overpay your mortgage or save?
item.content:encoded: Martin Lewis explains.

item.title: The real impact of roadworks on the country - and why they're set to get worse
item.content:encoded: There is a fine balance between the benefits of improved infrastructure, versus the cost of disruption. Does the country have it right?

item.title: Why the railways often seem to be in such chaos over Christmas
item.content:encoded: Parts of Britain’s rail network will close for engineering work over the festive period - but is that the right time to do it?

item.title: Budget 2025: What's the best and worst that could happen for Labour?
item.content:encoded: Three days in, after a tax U-turn and partial climbdown on workers' rights, Laura Kuenssberg looks at what impact Budget week might have.

item.title: Has Britain's budget watchdog become too all-powerful?
item.content:encoded: Ahead of this week's Budget, some have accused the Office for Budget Responsibility of being a "straitjacket on growth"

item.title: The curious case of why Poundland is struggling during a cost-of-living crisis
item.content:encoded: Why - in an age where so many of us are feeling the financial pinch - are some budget shops on UK high streets having such a tough time?
